content: The maritime industry, including commercial vessels like tankers, bulk carriers, and passenger ships, is regulated by international protocols and U.S. laws to prevent pollution. There are gaps in regulations, enforcement concerns, and a focus on the environmental impact of the cruise industry. Passenger ships make up 13% of the world shipping fleet, with the cruise industry being a significant contributor to the U.S. economy. The cruise industry, with ships making up 13% of the world shipping fleet, is a major contributor to the U.S. economy. In 2009, it provided $40 billion in benefits and over 357,000 U.S. jobs. However, the environmental impacts of its activities are a concern. The industry has seen a 7.4% annual growth rate in the number of passengers since 1990, with 14.3 million passengers in 2010. The fleet consists of over 230 ships, mostly foreign-flagged, with Liberia and Panama being popular flag countries. New ships are added each year, larger and more luxurious, with an average size increase of 90 feet every five years. The cruise ship industry faces challenges in managing large volumes of waste, including sewage, graywater, hazardous wastes, solid waste, and oily bilge water. Proper treatment and disposal of these wastes are crucial to prevent risks to human health and the environment. Environmental advocates have raised concerns about the adequacy of existing laws for waste management and enforcement. The 2000 General Accounting Office (GAO) report highlighted issues with cruise ship compliance with environmental regulations, revealing 87 confirmed illegal discharge cases in U.S. waters between 1993 and 1998. Most cases involved oil or oil-based product discharges, with some intentional and accidental. These cruise ship cases accounted for 4% of the total illegal discharge cases by foreign-flag ships during the six-year period studied by GAO. In response to environmental concerns, a coalition of advocacy groups petitioned the EPA in 2000 to address pollution by cruise ships. The EPA agreed to study cruise ship discharges and released a report in 2008 summarizing waste streams and findings from data collection activities, especially in Alaskan waters. Options to address ship pollution were identified in the report. The report provides information on cruise ship waste streams and recent data collection activities, focusing on ships operating in Alaskan waters. It discusses the types of waste generated, international and domestic laws addressing pollution, legislative activities in federal and state levels, and efforts by cruise ship companies to prevent illegal waste discharges. Cruise ships generate large amounts of graywater and solid waste, with graywater being a major source of liquid waste. Solid waste includes glass, paper, cardboard, aluminum, steel cans, and plastics, which can become marine debris and harm marine life. Waste management on cruise ships involves source reduction, waste minimization, recycling, and incineration, with some ash discharged at sea. This waste poses a threat to marine organisms, humans, coastal communities, and industries utilizing marine waters. Cruise ships generate large amounts of solid waste, including plastics, glass, aluminum, and paper. This waste is typically treated on board through incineration or pulping, with some ash discharged at sea. The disposal of waste from cruise ships can harm marine life, with each passenger generating around two pounds of non-hazardous solid waste per day. The amount of waste generated during a one-week cruise on a large ship can reach up to 8 tons. Additionally, cruise ships produce hazardous wastes from various onboard activities, putting a strain on port reception facilities. Cruise ships produce hazardous wastes from activities like photo processing, dry-cleaning, and equipment cleaning. These wastes contain substances like hydrocarbons, heavy metals, and chemicals that can harm marine organisms if not managed properly. Oil leaks from engine spaces can also pose threats to marine life and human health. The bilge, located at the lowest part of a ship, can contain harmful substances like oil, gasoline, and byproducts from petroleum breakdown. These substances can harm marine life and pose risks to human health. Bilge water may also contain solid wastes, pollutants, and chemicals from cleaning products used in the engine room. Large vessels can generate significant amounts of oily bilge water, which needs to be extracted before discharge to prevent environmental damage. The bilge water on ships needs to be extracted of oil before discharge to prevent environmental damage. If a separator is faulty or bypassed, untreated oily bilge water can harm marine life. Cruise ships and other vessels use ballast water for stability, taken on in one region and discharged in another to compensate for weight changes. This process is crucial for proper ship functioning. Ballast water discharge from ships, including cruise ships, contains biological materials that can introduce invasive species to marine ecosystems, leading to ecological, economic, and public health risks. The economic cost of pest mollusk introduction alone is estimated at $2.2 billion per year in the U.S. Further research is needed to understand the specific impact of cruise ships on this issue. Air pollution from cruise ships is a significant issue, with diesel engines burning high sulfur fuel and emitting harmful pollutants. EPA estimates that ocean-going vessels contribute to nitrogen oxide, particulate, and sulfur dioxide emissions in the U.S. Ships also emit greenhouse gases, making them a major source of air pollution. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) sets standards for maritime vessel safety and pollution prevention, such as the MARPOL 73/78 protocol. Cruise ships flagged under MARPOL signatory countries must comply with its requirements, regardless of where they sail. Ships flagged under MARPOL must adhere to its regulations, regardless of their location. The Convention consists of six Annexes covering various sources of pollution, including oil, noxious liquid substances, harmful substances, sewage, garbage, and emissions control. Member nations are responsible for vessels registered under their nationalities, and ratification and implementation by sovereign states are crucial for protecting the marine environment. Annex VI of MARPOL sets limits on emissions from marine vessels and prohibits deliberate emissions of ozone-depleting substances. Compliance with the Annexes is voluntary and requires ratification by member countries. The United States has ratified most Annexes, with the flag state responsible for certifying compliance. IMO has established other conventions for issues like ballast water management and passenger safety. The United States implements MARPOL through the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS) and regulations. Amendments to Annex VI were made in October 2008 after international negotiations. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, or Clean Water Act (CWA), is the principal U.S. law concerned with limiting polluting activity in the nation's water bodies. The National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) program controls pollutant discharges, including from vessels, requiring permits for discharge. The Clean Water Act prohibits pollutant discharges from vessels without a permit. EPA sets performance standards for MSDs while Coast Guard regulates design and operation. MSDs either hold sewage for disposal or treat it before discharge. MSDs are designed to hold or treat sewage before discharge. Coast Guard regulations cover three types of MSDs for large vessels, including cruise ships. Type II MSDs treat waste chemically or biologically and must meet specific limits. Type III MSDs store waste for later treatment onshore or outside U.S. waters. Type I MSDs disinfect sewage with chemicals and have specific performance standards. Regulations do not require monitoring or reporting of effluent discharges, with critics pointing out deficiencies in the current regulatory system. The regulations for Marine Sanitation Devices (MSDs) have not been updated since 1976, lacking requirements for sampling, monitoring, and reporting effluent discharges. Critics highlight deficiencies in the regulatory structure for cruise ships and large vessels, as MSD rules only cover bacterial contaminants and suspended solids, while NPDES permits for other sources regulate a wider range of pollutants. NPDES permit holders must comply with sampling, monitoring, and reporting requirements, unlike those under MSD rules. The Coast Guard, responsible for enforcing MSD regulations, has been criticized for inadequate inspections and enforcement of sewage treatment equipment on ships. The Coast Guard faces limitations in detecting violations of environmental laws due to factors like focus on safety, limited resources, and lack of surprise in inspections. Since 9/11, more resources have been allocated to homeland security, reducing time for vessel inspections for environmental compliance. The requirements are minimal and not mandatory in U.S. waters due to non-ratification. Discharges within three miles of shore must be treated, while discharges beyond 12 miles are unrestricted. Cruise ship solid waste discharges are regulated by the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act, requiring permits for dumping garbage into ocean waters. The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act governs hazardous waste management, imposing requirements on generators, transporters, and treatment/disposal facilities. The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) governs hazardous waste management for generators, transporters, and treatment/disposal facilities. The environmental groups challenged EPA's permitting exemption for ballast water discharges, leading to a court ruling that applies to other vessel discharges like graywater and bilge water. In response, EPA issued the Vessel General Permit in 2008, applicable to large recreational and commercial vessels, including tankers, freighters, and cruise ships. The permit covers pollutant discharges from non-recreational vessels over 79 feet in length and ballast water discharges from smaller commercial vessels and fishing vessels. It applies to waters of the United States in all states and territories. The Vessel General Permit (VGP) covers various waste streams from vessel operations, including aquatic nuisance species, nutrients, pathogens, oil, grease, metals, and toxic pollutants. Best management practices (BMPs) are used to control most waste streams, with specific requirements for ballast water and bilge water discharges. Monitoring, recordkeeping, and reporting are also included in the permit. The VGP includes BMPs and numeric effluent limits for certain discharges from cruise ships, such as graywater and pool water. Additional monitoring and reporting requirements are also imposed, with operational limits in nutrient-impaired waters. The permit does not cover sewage discharges or toxic wastes from passenger services on cruise ships. In Alaska, cruise ship pollution has raised concerns due to the significant increase in cruise ship visits during the 1990s. Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines faced penalties of $6.5 million for violations in Alaska, including knowingly discharging oil and hazardous substances. The company admitted to a fleet-wide practice of discharging oil-contaminated bilge water as part of a larger $18 million federal plea agreement involving environmental violations in multiple locations. Public concern about the violations led to the initiation of a program in December 1999 to identify cruise ship waste streams, revealing that waste treatment systems on most ships did not function well. Fecal coliform levels in blackwater and graywater greatly exceeded applicable U.S. Coast Guard standards. This attention to the Alaska issues led to the passage of federal legislation in December 2000. The federal legislation passed in December 2000 established standards for cruise ships in Alaska, prohibiting discharge of untreated sewage and graywater in navigable waters. EPA was authorized to set regulations for sewage and graywater discharges. Cruise ships can only discharge treated sewage wastes in Alaska waters while traveling at least 6 knots and 1 nautical mile from shore, with specific limits on fecal coliforms and total suspended solids. Discharges are also allowed within one mile from shore and at speeds less than 6 knots.
